awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A network-oriented research and education plan to explore links between forest cover and temperature in the eastern United States
awd_abstract_narration:
While the vast majority of the surface of the earth has warmed over the past century, in much of the eastern United States the air temperature has failed to rise or has even declined.  At the same time, forest cover over the region has increased dramatically, driven by abandonment of poor quality agricultural lands.  This project will test the hypothesis that reforestation in the eastern U.S. provides the explanation, in that it affects the surface energy balance in ways that lead to cooling and thus obscures long-term warming from climate change.  Just as human bodies are cooled by sweating or by a fan, forests may be cooled by greater rates of evapotranspiration and wind-driven movement of heat energy when compared to the croplands and grasslands they have replaced.  Looking forward, the rate of reforestation will decline over time as available space is filled, but the types of trees that fill in naturally or are planted will likely change.  Notably, drought-tolerant oaks are currently declining, while drought-sensitive maples and pines are proliferating.  So this work will also test a second hypothesis that ongoing regional shifts in tree species promote a reduction in evapotranspiration, particularly during periods of drought, that will tend to warm the surface.  The research will inform the development of sustainable agro-ecosystem management strategies that mitigate damaging effects of drought on ecosystem productivity and function.  A series of workshops will be developed, along with a citizen science program aimed at training young scientists in effective approaches for leveraging and analyzing network data.

The research will be enabled by interactions with a range of environmental observation networks, which aggregate meteorological and ecological observations from many ecosystems and thereby enable a big data approach to environmental science. Project outcomes are relevant to ongoing modelling efforts to reproduce historic climate trends and predict future conditions with more confidence. This work will advance network-driven environmental science by generating a rich collection of leaf- to ecosystem scale observations that will be shared with existing networks. The research is motivated by the recognition that, within the study region, ongoing management activities are driving a transition from forests dominated by species that are more anisohydric in their water use to forests dominated by more isohydric species. The concept of isohydry has received much attention in recent years, and this project will advance this body of knowledge by classifying important eastern U.S. species along the isohydric-anisohydric continuum, and developing a model for stomatal conductance that incorporates the isohydric-anisohydric framework.  While this project is focused on ecosystem energy balance, the project outcomes will also be relevant for efforts to understand regional carbon and water cycling, and for the development of forest management strategies that mitigate deleterious effects of drought on ecosystem functioning

por.por_cntn:
Over the past century, air temperature has increased over the vast majority of the earth's land surface. However, across much of the Eastern US, temperature has increased only slightly or not at all. Over the same time period, the Eastern US has experienced a remarkable land disturbance history characterized by widespread reforestation of abandoned agricultural lands that began in the early 1900s. When compared to grasslands and croplands, forests evaporate more water and enhance heat transfer away from the surface – processes that tend to lower the land surface temperature. Thus, this project’s overall objective was to quantify the extent to which eastern US forests cool the surface and near-surface air, and to evaluate whether this cooling benefit may have contributed to the Eastern U.S. warming hole. The objective was met by blending: 1) observations of terrestrial energy and water cycling from flux towers across the study region, 2) satellite-derived information on temperature and land cover, and 4) information contained in a long-term meteorological station network (The US Historic Climatology network) and multiple meteorological reanalysis products.

 

Overall, results show that eastern US reforestation substantially reduces surface temperature during midday summer periods (by between 2-5 deg C). Importantly, the cooling benefit of eastern US forests extends to the near-surface air temperature, though the magnitude is reduced to 0.5-1 degrees C on midday summer periods. We show that this air cooling benefit has played an important role in reducing historic anthropogenic warming across the study region.

 

Looking forward, the fate of these benefits depends on the interaction between forest management activities and our changing climate. Most of the region’s forests are experiencing a long-term and persistent decline in oaks, which are being replaced by maples and other species that are better adapted to management-driven reductions in fire frequency. Thus, projecting forest carbon and energy cycles into the future requires an understanding of how individual species (e.g. oaks, maples) respond to the increasingly frequent and severe drought events expected in the future. A wealth of new data and network observations were blended together to reveal that Eastern US oaks have a unique drought response strategy: they sustain photosynthesis and growth during periods of both soil and atmospheric drought stress, despite having vascular systems that are especially vulnerable to failure when photosynthesis is sustained during drought. From the perspective of understanding the climatic benefits of Eastern US forests, this means that the loss of oaks will create stands that are more vulnerable to reductions in carbon uptake and evaporative cooling potential during drought.

 

A defining feature of the work proposed here is its reliance on observations acquired from, or shared to, environmental observation networks, including Ameriflux, NSF’s National Ecological Observation Network (NEON), and the United States Historical Climate Network (HCN). Thus, the project’s success depended on recruiting and training young scientists to work effectively in a network-enabled context. This was accomplished through: 1)  the PI’s role in co-organizing and sustaining the Fluxcourse – an annual, two-week workshop course that exposes students and postdocs to the fundamentals of ecosystem flux measurement, modeling, and network synthesis, 2) the PI’s role in advising the research and education activities of both NEON and AmeriFlux through service on each networks advisory committee, 3) developing a new land-atmosphere interactions course for PhD students at Indiana University, which emphasized network-enabled approaches and 4) engaging K-12 students and teachers in citizen-science phenology monitoring activities, generating data that were analyzed for what they reveal about phenological impacts on carbon cycling, and also shared publicly through phenology networks like Project Budburst and the US National Phenology Network.  

 

Overall, the project contributed to the training of ~20 early career scientists. Several of the project personnel were recruited through participation in Indiana University programs designed to broaden racial diversity in the biological sciences, including the Jim Holland Summer Science Research Program for high school students of color, and the IU Groups STEM scholars program for incoming college students from under-represented demographics.

 

Finally, the outcomes of this project have broad connections to growing public and private sector interest in so-called “natural climate solutions” (NCS) ‘like reforestation. While the carbon benefits of Eastern US forests are well-recognized, this work demonstrates an additional climate adaptation potential linked to direct reductions in surface and near-surface air temperature. Motivated by these results, in early 2021, the PI co-founded a new AmeriFlux network working group on natural climate solutions, which has: 1) published a paper describing strategies for leveraging flux network data to inform NCS potentials, 2) organized multiple conference sessions and a special journal issue, and 3) begun the task of organizing two workshops (to occur in June and November of 2022) which will bring the carbon cycle science community together with public- and private-sector organizations seeking ways to inform NCS with the best-available science.

Modified by: Kimberly A Novick
